segment.source: Lab 1a: Create a basic image
segment.target: Lab 1a: Create a basic image

segment.source: Lab 1a: Create a basic image
segment.target: Lab 1a: Create a basic image

segment.source: This content has been tested on Windows 10 IoT Core Build 10586.
segment.target: This content has been tested on Windows 10 IoT Core Build 10586.

segment.source: Some of these procedures do not yet work on newer preview builds, including Windows 10, version 1607.
segment.target: Some of these procedures do not yet work on newer preview builds, including Windows 10, version 1607.

segment.source: To get started, we'll create a basic Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core) image, flash it to a micro SD card, and put it into a device to make sure that everything's working properly.
segment.target: To get started, we'll create a basic Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core) image, flash it to a micro SD card, and put it into a device to make sure that everything's working properly.

segment.source: We'll create a product folder that represents our first design.
segment.target: We'll create a product folder that represents our first design.

segment.source: For our first product design, we'll customize just enough for the IoT core device to boot up and run the built-in OOBE app, which we should be able to see on an HDMI-compatible monitor.
segment.target: For our first product design, we'll customize just enough for the IoT core device to boot up and run the built-in OOBE app, which we should be able to see on an HDMI-compatible monitor.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: See Get the tools needed to customize Windows IoT Core to get your technician PC ready.
segment.target: See Get the tools needed to customize Windows IoT Core to get your technician PC ready.

segment.source: Create a basic image
segment.target: Create a basic image

segment.source: Set your OEM name (one-time only)
segment.target: Set your OEM name (one-time only)

segment.source: Open the file C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitToolssetOEM.cmd in Notepad, and modify it with your company name.
segment.target: Open the file C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitToolssetOEM.cmd in Notepad, and modify it with your company name.

segment.source: We've added this variable to help you create packages with names that are easy to differentiate from those provided from other manufacturers you're working with.
segment.target: We've added this variable to help you create packages with names that are easy to differentiate from those provided from other manufacturers you're working with.

segment.source: Start the IoT Core shell, choose your architecture, and install test certificates
segment.target: Start the IoT Core shell, choose your architecture, and install test certificates

segment.source: In Windows Explorer, go to the folder where you installed the IoT Core ADK Add-Ons, for example, C:IoT-ADK-AddonKit, and open IoTCoreShell.cmd.
segment.target: In Windows Explorer, go to the folder where you installed the IoT Core ADK Add-Ons, for example, C:IoT-ADK-AddonKit, and open IoTCoreShell.cmd.

segment.source: It should prompt you to run as an administrator.
segment.target: It should prompt you to run as an administrator.

segment.source: The new value for OEMNAME should appear when you start the tool.
segment.target: The new value for OEMNAME should appear when you start the tool.

segment.source: Troubleshooting: Error: "The system cannot find the path specified".
segment.target: Troubleshooting: Error: "The system cannot find the path specified".

segment.source: If you get this, right-click the icon and modify the path in "Target" to the location you've chosen to install the tools.
segment.target: If you get this, right-click the icon and modify the path in "Target" to the location you've chosen to install the tools.

segment.source: At the Set Environment for Architecture prompt, select 1 for ARM or 2 for x86, based on the architecture for the boards that you'll be developing.
segment.target: At the Set Environment for Architecture prompt, select 1 for ARM or 2 for x86, based on the architecture for the boards that you'll be developing.

segment.source: For example, press 1 to create an image that's compatible with the Raspberry Pi 2 or Raspberry Pi 3, or press 2 to create an image that's compatible with the Minnowboard Max.
segment.target: For example, press 1 to create an image that's compatible with the Raspberry Pi 2 or Raspberry Pi 3, or press 2 to create an image that's compatible with the Minnowboard Max.

segment.source: The launch tool sets the default architecture, and sets a version number for the design, which you can use for future updates.
segment.target: The launch tool sets the default architecture, and sets a version number for the design, which you can use for future updates.

segment.source: The first version number defaults to 10.0.0.0.
segment.target: The first version number defaults to 10.0.0.0.

segment.source: (Why a four-part version number?
segment.target: (Why a four-part version number?

segment.source: Learn about versioning schemes in Update requirements.)
segment.target: Learn about versioning schemes in Update requirements.)

segment.source: One-time tasks
segment.target: One-time tasks

segment.source: These tasks only need to be done the first time you install the IoT ADK AddonKit.
segment.target: These tasks only need to be done the first time you install the IoT ADK AddonKit.

segment.source: Install OEM test certificates.
segment.target: Install OEM test certificates.

segment.source: You'll use these to sign your test binaries.
segment.target: You'll use these to sign your test binaries.

segment.source: The certificates are added to the root.
segment.target: The certificates are added to the root.

segment.source: To learn more, see Set up the signing environment
segment.target: To learn more, see Set up the signing environment

segment.source: Build all of the packages in the working folders.
segment.target: Build all of the packages in the working folders.

segment.source: Create a new test image
segment.target: Create a new test image

segment.source: Create a new product folder.
segment.target: Create a new product folder.

segment.source: This folder represents a new device we want to build, and contains sample customization files that we can use to start our project.
segment.target: This folder represents a new device we want to build, and contains sample customization files that we can use to start our project.

segment.source: This creates the folder: C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-archProductsProductA.
segment.target: This creates the folder: C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-archProductsProductA.

segment.source: Eject any removable storage drives, including the Micro SD card and any USB flash drives.
segment.target: Eject any removable storage drives, including the Micro SD card and any USB flash drives.

segment.source: Create a flashable test image using the default files.
segment.target: Create a flashable test image using the default files.

segment.source: Test images include additional tools, and you can create test images using either signed or unsigned test packages.
segment.target: Test images include additional tools, and you can create test images using either signed or unsigned test packages.

segment.source: This creates a FFU file with your basic image at C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchProductATest.
segment.target: This creates a FFU file with your basic image at C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchProductATest.

segment.source: Troubleshooting:
segment.target: Troubleshooting:

segment.source: ERROR CODES: 0x80070005 or 0x800705b4: Reopen the IoT Core Shell as an administrator, unplug all external drives (including micro SD cards and USB thumb drives), and try again.
segment.target: ERROR CODES: 0x80070005 or 0x800705b4: Reopen the IoT Core Shell as an administrator, unplug all external drives (including micro SD cards and USB thumb drives), and try again.

segment.source: If this doesn't work, go back to Set up your PC and download the samples and make sure everything's installed.
segment.target: If this doesn't work, go back to Set up your PC and download the samples and make sure everything's installed.

segment.source: Flash the image to a memory card
segment.target: Flash the image to a memory card

segment.source: Start the Windows IoT Core Dashboard.
segment.target: Start the Windows IoT Core Dashboard.

segment.source: Plug your micro SD card into your technician PC, and select it in the tool.
segment.target: Plug your micro SD card into your technician PC, and select it in the tool.

segment.source: From Setup a new device, select Device Type: Custom.
segment.target: From Setup a new device, select Device Type: Custom.

segment.source: From Flash the pre-downloaded file (Flash.ffu) to the SD card, click Browse, browse to your FFU file (C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchProductATestProductA.ffu), then click Next.
segment.target: From Flash the pre-downloaded file (Flash.ffu) to the SD card, click Browse, browse to your FFU file (C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchProductATestProductA.ffu), then click Next.

segment.source: Accept the license terms, and then click Install.
segment.target: Accept the license terms, and then click Install.

segment.source: The Windows IoT Core Dashboard formats the micro SD card and installs the new image.
segment.target: The Windows IoT Core Dashboard formats the micro SD card and installs the new image.

segment.source: Boot it up
segment.target: Boot it up

segment.source: Connect your IoT device, such as a Raspberry Pi 2, into a monitor using an HDMI cable.
segment.target: Connect your IoT device, such as a Raspberry Pi 2, into a monitor using an HDMI cable.

segment.source: Note When possible, use a direct connection to an HDMI port.
segment.target: Note When possible, use a direct connection to an HDMI port.

segment.source: The display may not appear when using DVI/VGA adapters or hubs.
segment.target: The display may not appear when using DVI/VGA adapters or hubs.

segment.source: Put in the micro SD card with your image.
segment.target: Put in the micro SD card with your image.

segment.source: Power it on.
segment.target: Power it on.

segment.source: After a short while, the device should start automatically, and you should see the default app (code-named "Bertha"), which shows basic info about the image.
segment.target: After a short while, the device should start automatically, and you should see the default app (code-named "Bertha"), which shows basic info about the image.

segment.source: Note Some devices may be extremely slow to boot up on the first boot when using some 8GB class 10 SD cards.
segment.target: Note Some devices may be extremely slow to boot up on the first boot when using some 8GB class 10 SD cards.

segment.source: Slow boot times may be over 15 minutes.
segment.target: Slow boot times may be over 15 minutes.

segment.source: Subsequent boots will be much quicker on the affected cards.
segment.target: Subsequent boots will be much quicker on the affected cards.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: Leave the device on for now, and continue to Lab 1b: Add an app to your image.
segment.target: Leave the device on for now, and continue to Lab 1b: Add an app to your image.
